Name: shi hu
石斛
Biological: Dendrobium fimbriatum Hook var. oculatum Hook (馬鞭石斛)
Dendrobium officinale Kimura et Migo (鐵皮石斛)

Maladies Treated: weakness after febrile diseases; injury of fluids due to febrile disease or post-illness weakness with fluid deficiency thirst
thromboangitis obliterans (闭塞性周圍血管病)
Dosage: Dry herb: 7–15 g. Fresh herb: 15–38 g.
Samples of Formulae:
Name of formula: Shi Hu Ye Guang Wan (石斛夜光丸) [Source: Yuan Ji Qi Wei 原機啟微]
Application: cataract, glaucoma, with yinxu (yin deficient) condition.
Functions and indications: 滋陰補腎，清肝明目.
Composition and processing:
- Shi Hu (Dendrobium stem) wine-washed, 5 qian.
- Ren Shen (Ginseng root) 1 liang; Sheng Di (Rehmannia root, raw) 1 liang; Shu Di (Rehmannia root, prepared) wine-washed, 1 liang; Mai Men Dong (Ophiopogon root) 1 liang; Tian Men Dong (Asparagus tuber) 1 liang; Bai Fu Ling (Poria) 1 liang; Fang Feng (Saposhnikovia root) 1 liang; Cao Jue Ming (Cassia seed) 1 liang; Huang Lian (Coptis rhizome) wine-fried, 1 liang.
- Ling Yang Jiao (Antelope horn) 5 qian; Xi Jiao (Rhinoceros horn) 5 qian (or use Niu Jiao [Water buffalo horn] concentrated powder 1 liang).
- Chuan Xiong (Ligusticum chuanxiong rhizome) 5 qian; Zhi Gan Cao (Honey-fried Licorice root) 5 qian; Zhi Ke (Bitter orange) fried, 5 qian; Qing Xiang Zi (Celosia seed) lightly stir-fried, 5 qian; Wu Wei Zi (Schisandra fruit) fried, 5 qian; Rou Cong Rong (Cistanche) wine-washed, remove scales, dry-fried, 5 qian.
- Niu Xi (Achyranthes root) wine-washed, 7 qian; Bai Ji Li (Tribulus fruit) fried and de-thorned, 7 qian; Tu Si Zi (Cuscuta seed) processed, 7 qian; Ju Hua (Chrysanthemum flower) 7 qian; Shan Yao (Dioscorea yam rhizome) 7 qian; Xing Ren (Apricot kernel) 7 qian; Gou Qi (Lycium fruit) 7 qian.
Preparation: Grind into powder. Refine with honey to make pills. Make large honey pills, each weighing 9 g.
Dosage and administration: Take one pill each time. Use warm wine or salted soup to swallow.
Notes: There are Shi Hu Ye Guang Wan products produced in mainland China that did not pass inspection of the health department in Taiwan. Xi Jiao (Rhinoceros horn) can be substituted with concentrated extract of water buffalo horn (using concentrated powder is more convenient).
Contraindications: Reports state that large dosages caused inhibiting effects on heart and lung functions in laboratory animals, and overdoses caused convulsion. Controlled under the Washington Treaty (CITES) Appendix II; permit required for import and export trade. Controlled materials listed: Dendrobium nobile Lindl. (金釵石斛); Dendrobium fimbriatum Hook var. oculatum Hook (馬鞭石斛); Dendrobium chryanthum Wall. (黃草石斛); Dendrobium candidum (耳環石斛); Dendrobium loddigesii (環草石斛).

Maladies Treated: Hemoptysis: decoction of di jin cao (creeping euphorbia) 9–12 g, taken morning and night; effective for small and medium hemoptysis, less effective in large hemoptysis
Bacillary dysentery: decoction of di jin cao (creeping euphorbia) 30 g, tie xian cai 30 g, feng wei cao 30 g, taken orally
Bruises, swelling: appropriate amount of fresh di jin cao (creeping euphorbia) smashed with rice wine lees and some wheat flour and applied topically
Functional uterine bleeding (gong xue bing): di jin cao (creeping euphorbia) 1,000 g boiled with water, remove solid, simmer to paste; take 4.5 g with rice wine, twice daily
Coughing up blood, vomiting blood, blood in the stool, uterine bleeding: di jin cao (creeping euphorbia) 30 g decoction taken orally; honey can be added
Herpes zoster: fresh di jin cao (creeping euphorbia) mashed and mixed with vinegar, apply the juice to the affected area
Lack of mother's milk: di jin cao (creeping euphorbia) 21 g with pig foot decocted; remove solid, add 60 g sweet rice wine, drink while warm
Medical Function: Clearing heat and detoxifying
Helping rid of dampness and resolving jaundice
Improving circulation and stopping bleeding
Anti-microorganism: flavonoids possess broad-spectrum in vitro inhibition of bacteria

Detoxification: strong inhibitory effect on diphtheria bacilli and strong neutralizing effect on diphtheria bacillus exotoxin; 100%, 50% and 25% di jin cao tincture mixed with diphtheria exotoxin at low temperature for 30 minutes and injected subcutaneously in guinea pigs showed obvious neutralizing effect on IMLD or aMLD exotoxin and reduced animal mortality; decoction effect not obvious
Hemostatic: topical di jin cao powder showed hemostatic effects on experimental canine femoral artery incision bleeding

Mitigates benzene hexachloride toxicity on mouse tissue pathology: prevents damage to heart, liver, spleen, kidney tissues caused by 14% industrial benzene hexachloride 200 ppm; long-term feeding caused mild granular degeneration of liver and myocardium in experimental animals; no effect on kidneys; excitatory effects on spleen and liver hematopoietic system with increased lymphocytes and primitive neuroblastic cells
Anti-HBV activity [2]
Dosage: Internal: decoction 10–15 g; if using fresh herb: 15–30 g; may also be made into powder. External: appropriate amount; smash fresh herb and apply or make into powder and apply on affected areas.
Samples of Formulae:
Treatment of hemoptysis: di jin cao (creeping euphorbia) 9–12 g; make into decoction. Take morning and night. It is effective for small and medium hemoptysis. It is less effective in large hemoptysis. No side effects. (Zhong Yao Da Ci Dian - Great Chinese Herbal Dictionary)

Treatment of bacillary dysentery: di jin cao (creeping euphorbia) 30 g, tie xian cai 30 g, feng wei cao 30 g. Make into decoction and take orally. (Single Prescriptions and Proven Recipes Selection)

Treatment of bruises, swelling: use appropriate amount of fresh di jin cao (creeping euphorbia) and smash evenly with rice wine lees and some wheat flour and apply topically. (Hunan Medicine Journal)

Treatment of functional uterine bleeding (gong xue bing): di jin cao (creeping euphorbia) 1,000 g. Boil with water. Remove solid and simmer the decoction to make paste. Take 4.5 g with rice wine, twice daily. (Inner Mongolia "Chinese Herbal Medicine Selection")

Treatment of coughing up blood, vomiting blood, blood in the stool, uterine bleeding: di jin cao (creeping euphorbia) 30 g. Make into decoction and take orally. Honey can also be added. (Fujian Chinese Herbal Medicine)

Herpes zoster: fresh di jin cao (creeping euphorbia), mash and add vinegar. Stir. Apply the juice to the affect area. (Fujian Chinese Herbal Medicine)

For treatment of lack of mother's milk: di jin cao (creeping euphorbia) 21 g, pig foot. Make into decoction. Remove solid. Add 60 g of sweet rice wine. Drink while warm. (Jianxi Folk Herbal Medicine)
Contraindications: Using di jin cao decoction concentrated ethanol extract intragastric administration to rabbits (20 g crude herb / kg) and observed for one week, or using gavage to rats (15 g crude herb / kg) twice daily for 16 consecutive days. After discontinuation, observed for one week and did not find anything abnormal. The toxicity of this herb is mild. Using di jin cao tablets (decoction alcohol extract) intragastric administration to rabbits 20 g/kg 1 time, and observed for one week or intragastric administration to rats 15 g/kg, 2 times per day for 16 days and after discontinuation, observed for 1 week and the animals showed nothing abnormal.
Research:
Medical functions (pharmacology):
1. Anti-microorganism that cause illnesses: The flavonoids of this herb possesses broad-spectrum in vitro inhibition of bacteria.

2. Detoxification effect: The herb not only possesses a strong inhibitory effect on diphtheria bacilli, but also shows a strong neutralizing effect on diphtheria bacillus exotoxin. Experiments show that after 30 minutes in low temperature, the 100%, 50% and 25% of the di jin cao tincture with diphtheria exotoxin using subcutaneous injection in guinea pig, diphtheria exotoxin of IMLD or aMLD show obvious neutralizing effect, and can reduce animal mortality, but the effect of the decoction is not obvious.

3. Hemostatic effect: using di jin cao powder for topical application showed hemostatic effects of experimental canines on femoral artery bleeding caused by incision.

4. Mitigate toxic effects of benzene hexachloride on mouse tissue pathology: 14% industrial Benzene hexachloride 200 ppm can cause serious damage on animal heart, liver, spleen and kidney tissues. Vitamin C 4000 ppm reduces tissue lesions caused by benzene hexachloride, but di jin cao can prevent damage to the organs. A long time feeding di jin cao caused mild granular degeneration on liver and myocardium in experimental animals, and had no effect on the kidneys, spleen and liver hematopoietic system excitatory effects and increased of lymphocytes and primitive neuroblastic cells. Note: Benzene hexachloride (六六六; hexachlorobenzene) molecular formula C6H6Cl6; English is Benzene hexachloride (BHC).

5. Anti HBV activity [2].
Notes: Chinese portion is from Zhong Hua Ben Cao. Euphorbia supina Raf. is listed as 斑葉地錦 in the source.

Samples of Formulae:
For paralysis after stroke; also for spastic muscles:
Prescription: Tian Ma (Gastrodia tuber) 3 portions; Niu Xi (Achyranthes root) 3 portions; Du Zhong (Eucommia bark) 3 portions; Dang Gui (Angelica sinensis root) 2 portions; Qiang Huo (Notopterygium root) 2 portions. Grind into fine powder. Mix with refined honey to make into cubes. Take 5 g each time, 3 times daily, with warm boiled water. Source: Long Xiang Fei.

Indications: Limb and muscular spasm; hemiplegia after stroke.

For limb spasm, numbness of hands and feet, soreness of waist and legs, migraine:
Tian Ma Wan (Tian Ma Pills).
Tian Ma Gou Teng Yin (Gastrodia and Uncaria Decoction).

Traditional combinations: Tian Ma (Gastrodia tuber) with Gou Teng (Uncaria hook), Ban Xia (Pinellia rhizome), Chuan Xiong (Ligusticum chuanxiong rhizome), Fang Feng (Saposhnikovia root).
Contraindications: Should not be used in case of yinxu (yin deficient) 陰虛者忌用。
Notes:
Present day usage: for epilepsy; for external injury of the brain; as a painkiller; for neurasthenia; for depression; for the blood-vessel type of migraine. It has no undesirable side effects. It does not create a tolerance.

Identification (Differentiation): Tian ma is long and elliptical, shrunk, crooked and slightly flat, 3–15 cm long, 1.5–6 cm wide, and 0.5–2 cm thick. At one end of the tuber, there is a reddish-brown withered bud or a remaining stem. At the other end, there is an umbilicate scar. The tuber is usually peeled. Its surface is yellowish white or yellowish brown with longitudinal wrinkles and some spotted segmental rings. It is hard and semi-transparent and does not break easily. The cross-section is smooth and lustrous. It has a peculiar odor and a sweet, slightly pungent taste.

Fake/adulterants (do not use as substitutes): roots of Mirabilis jalapa L. and Dahlia pinnata Cav., or the tuber of potato Solanum tuberosum L.; also Cacalia tangutica Hand.-Mazz., Canna edulis Ker., Colocasia esculenta (L.) Schott, Dobinea delavayi Engl., and more than ten other plant roots or tubers. These lack the spotted segmental rings and longitudinal wrinkles on the surface, and the cross-section has no resin-like luster.

Classical records: Earliest description in Shen Nong Ben Cao Jing (Qin/Han dynasties, about 2,200 years ago), listed as top quality herb. Mentioned by Ge Hong (283–343 A.D.) in Bao Po Zi. Also described in Tang Ben Cao (completed 659 A.D.) and Tu Jing Ben Cao (completed 1061 A.D.).

Regulatory/Conservation: This herb belongs to controlled material of CITES (Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora), Appendix II; permit required for import and export trade.

Toxicity: Relatively safe.

At one end of the tuber, there is a reddish-brown withered bud or a remaining stem. At the other end, there is an umbilicate scar. Tian ma ( Gastrodia) tuber is usually peeled. Its surface is yellowish white or yellowish brown with longitudinal wrinkles and some spotted segmental rings. It is hard and semi-transparent. It does not break easily.  Its cross-section is smooth and lustrous. It has a peculiar odor and a sweet, slightly pungent taste.   Fakes are the roots of Mirabilis jalapa L. and Dahlia pinnata Cav., or the tuber of potato, Solanum tuberosum L.
